ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HIGHER SCHOOL CERTIFICATE TEACHERS
(Salary increment)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Education whether teachers with the Higher School Certificate, whether in Government or Government-aided schools and in any of the four language streams, are given one increment more than those with the School Certificate: whether some teachers with the Higher School Certificate have not been given the additional increment, and if he will put the matter right.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a scheme whereby non-graduate teachers with the Cambridge Overseas Higher School Certificate are given one additional increment if they teach in secondary schools and for so long as they teach in secondary schools. This applies to both Government and Government-aided school teachers. This scheme is confined to the English medium, because when the scheme was promulgated in July 1962, there was a dearth of graduates for the English medium secondary schools, and it was essential to encourage Primary-trained teachers with the School Certificate in this medium to take the higher qualification of the H.S.C. to enable them to teach in secondary schools.

Column: 780



    There are no teachers in the English medium who satisfy the requirement and who have not been paid the additional increment. There are, however, teachers in the English medium with the H.S.C. teaching in Primary schools who have not been paid this increment, because the requirement is that they must teach in secondary schools.

    As this scheme was originated to cope with the shortage of graduate teachers in the English medium, there are, therefore, teachers in the other media who do not qualify for the additional increment.

SINGAPORE SWEEP TICKETS
(Figures and proceeds)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance if he knows how many Singapore Sweep tickets have been sold up to a latest convenient date; and what percentage of the proceeds is collected by Government and what percentage is retained by the Singapore Turf Club.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Sweep is run by the Singapore Turf Club. According to the Singapore Turf Club, 2½ million tickets were printed for the first draw and all the tickets have been sold. The Singapore Turf Club has agreed to hand over to the Government the entire proceeds from the sale of tickets after deducting running expenses, payment of prizes, and agents' commission. The sum which the Singapore Turf Club is deducting for running expenses is approximately 3.2 per cent of the gross proceeds of the lottery.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE TO
OLD-AGED PERSONS AND WIDOWS


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs if he will consider increasing the amount of public assistance in respect of old-aged persons and widows.

Column: 781



    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, public assistance payments are made by the Social Welfare Department to unemployed persons, including aged persons and widows, at approved rates which have already been increased on two occasions under this Government, i.e., in 1959 and 1962. These rates of unemployment benefits, under which a large family can receive as much as $90 per month, are generally acknowledged to be the highest paid in this part of the world, and it is not considered desirable to increase the rates further. Under this scheme, an aged couple who are on their own and have no one to provide for them, will receive $31 per month and a widow with, say, four dependent children will receive $41 per month.

    I am, however, aware of the special needs of aged persons and widows, and there are special allowances over and above the public assistance payments for which they are eligible. These aged persons can receive, in addition to the public assistance payments, a special old-age allowance of $12 per month for a single person and $18 for a couple, if they are 65 years old and above, from the Silver Jubilee Fund, a charitable fund which is also administered by the Social Welfare Department.

    I should also mention that the Social Welfare Department runs Old People's Homes to which destitute aged persons with no relatives or friends to look after them can be admitted. Widows are also eligible to receive, in addition to their public assistance payments, special educational grants of $5 per month per child in primary schools and $8 per month per child in secondary schools from the Silver Jubilee Fund. I should, however, like to assure the hon. Member that cases of aged persons or widows receiving public assistance with any special problems will be reviewed sympathetically if they are brought to my attention.

Column: 783

you carry out your job, the sooner you go out of business! In fact, by the present going, I think the Adult Education Board is doing very well, and here I must pay a tribute to the Board. All I want to know is what plans the Minister has for the future of the Board.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Adult Education Board not only conducts literacy and language classes, but also other extra-mural courses to cater for the vocational, civic and recreational interests of the public. With our present trend of education and the ability to provide universal primary education to all our school-age pupils, without compulsion, there may come a time when there may not be a demand for the literacy and language classes conducted by the Board. But I do not think the Board will go into liquidation, because there are other activities currently run by the Board.

    I agree with the Member for Changi that there are large numbers of unemployed young people in Singapore and that the Government should, wherever possible, provide gainful employment for them. It is in line with this policy that towards the end of 1964 the Adult Education Board was asked by the Ministry of Education to consider providing opportunities for employment for the unemployed. However, since unemployment is more acute amongst the Chinese than the English medium, a pilot plan was implemented in 1965 mainly directed at the Chinese medium to replace 25 per cent of its teachers by qualified but unemployed persons who have the following qualifications:

    (a) School leavers with Chinese medium school certificate or Higher School Certificates with the required minimum educational qualifications for recruitment as teachers-in-training;

    (b) Graduates of Nanyang University;

Column: 784



    (c) Experienced and/or trained teachers who have been retired on grounds of age or redundancy.

    In 1966 the Board organised a short but intensive course to train them. This training course was conducted by the staff of the Teachers' Training College and the practical teaching was supervised by Inspectors of Schools and T.T.C. lecturers. An examination was also conducted at the end of the course, and only successful candidates were retained in the part-time employment offered by the Board.

    At present there are 57 out of a total or 147 teachers, or nearly 38 per cent, in the literacy and language classes, and 75 out of 165 teachers, or nearly 45 per cent, in the secondary evening classes who are recruited from the unemployed. Furthermore, all the 26 second-language teachers in the Secondary I and literacy and language classes in the English medium also came from the same source. However, part-time trained teachers from Government or Government-aided schools, because of their experience and professional training, are retained in the Board to teach senior classes, whereas those recruited from the unemployed, after they have been given an intensive training course, are teaching only the Secondary I, II and literacy and language classes.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, recently a feeling of uneasiness was experienced by parents of students in Malay schools because of the direction that the uniform of girl students in Malay secondary schools should be changed from baju kurong to skirt and blouse type of school uniform. It is stated that this type of school uniform is more progressive than baju kurong. There are others who say that Malay students are Muslims and to put on skirt and blouse is forbidden. The Chairman of U.M.N.O., Singapore, Inche Ahmad Bin Haji Taff, in wanting to safeguard the personality of the students and Malay culture, has resisted the idea of changing the baju kurong to skirt and blouse. Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion, whether the students are progressive or not does not depend on their uniform; it does not matter whether

Column: 787

the school uniform is baju kurong or skirt and blouse. It depends on the education imparted to them by the teachers in the schools and the encouragement they get to study at home. Whether it is acceptable (halal) or forbidden (haram) depends on each individual. Today there are many Malay girls who put on dresses which are transparent, and skin tight too. So, in order to safeguard Malay culture and personality, does Inche Ahmad Haji Taff himself put on baju kurong when he goes to work in the office? The attitude of this gentleman is like that of the mother crab which asks its baby to walk straight when she herself walks sideways. It is better that the question of deciding on the school dress, whether it is to be baju kurong or skirt and blouse, be left to the parents themselves so long as there is a distinctive colour in the uniform according to the school the child attends. Also consideration should be given to the extra expenditure that may be incurred by parents. But what is most important is to look into the matter of the progress of the children's education.

    The Minister, in replying to the Member for Sembawang earlier, stated that at the moment there are very few qualified trained Malay teachers to teach in Malay secondary schools. Therefore, with this shortage, can Malay secondary students become more progressive only by changing their dress from baju kurong to skirt and blouse? If the Ministry of Education are aware of this shortage, they should then find ways and means to overcome this shortage if they truly wish to see Malay students progress in their studies. I still remember the Minister for Education during the Government of Tun Lim Yew Hock in 1957 stated that Malay secondary schools could not be established because there were no teachers and no suitable text-books in Malay. But when the P.A.P. came to power in 1959, the then Minister for Education, who is now the Minister for Health, promised that Malay secondary schools would be established in 1961, although he was still facing the same problem of teachers and textbooks in Malay. But because of the keen

Column: 788

effort put in, Malay secondary classes were started in 1960, that is, one year earlier. If the present Minister for Education is to wait for qualified teachers in the Malay stream to descend from heaven, and likewise wait for textbooks to descend from heaven, then the intention to see that Malay education progresses will not be achieved. I would like to ask the Minister what plans there are to encourage more Malay graduate teachers, because at present although there are a number of Malay graduates, they were transferred or ask for transfer to other jobs for specific reasons.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would further like to state that, at the moment, there are one or two pre-university classes in the Malay stream. If the problem facing Malay secondary education cannot be faced by the Ministry, what hope is there for those in the pre-university classes? What will happen to those students who wish to go for further studies? Does the Ministry have any plans to overcome this problem?

    Regarding vocational education in the Malay stream, I find that it is important to increase the number of vocational schools in the Malay stream so as to give opportunities to Malay students to study in the vocational stream in order that they will be well equipped to work in factories and industries which need skilled workers. I hope the Minister will see to it that vocational schools in the Malay stream be increased so as to enable Malay students to get vocational training.

3.00 p.m.

    Regarding text-books, I have received complaints that certain schools change text-books from year to year. This causes difficulties to parents who have two or more children in the same school, whereas it is the policy of the Ministry of Education to provide opportunities for them to give their children adequate education. If textbooks are changed from year to year, this will be a problem to the parents, because the textbooks which could have been handed down to the other children cannot be handed down. I hope that efforts will be made

Column: 789

to see that textbooks in the schools could be used in a manner that would not bring difficulty to the parents.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, education is essential in any society. In a developing multi-racial, multi-lingual, multi-religious socialist society like ours, however, education is called on to do more than just training our young. It is also called on to make us good and useful citizens, to weld our nation together. In the past we lived not as a nation. We could not have done that because we were then a subject race. In the past we lived in separate communities. Things are now different. We are now independent and our destiny is in our own hands. We are responsible for our own future. We are, however, a small nation living on a small island with no natural resources. The only resources that we can boast of are our own people our skill in training, in manufacturing and in other fields.

    The purpose of education, therefore, should be to train and nurture these skills to make us good and useful citizens. Education, however, does not consist of cramming up all the facts that we can lay our hands on - in being what we call a book-worm or a walking dictionary. The aim of education is to make us a complete man, a man who can think and act for himself, a man with a disciplined mind and a healthy body. We can only achieve this by two branches of education, namely, literary education and physical education. In the very recent past, Mr Speaker, Sir, our education system was defective to the extent that we attached far too much importance to literary education and not enough importance to physical education. A devotion to one branch of education to the exclusion of the other branch would not serve the purpose of education. Unmitigated attention to physical education, for example, would produce a sort of ferocity in us, a sort of uncivilised harshness that we should avoid. On the other hand, a mere literary education makes us soft and dispirited, something that is not good for us. Ferocity, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the outcome of the spirited element in us. Proper training would produce

Column: 790

courage. But if that element is over-strained, it naturally becomes hard and savage. Gentleness, on the other hand, is characteristic of the philosophic disposition. Here again, too much relaxation will result in over-softness. The right training would produce a gentleness that is steady and disciplined. We all know the saying: "All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy." All class-work and no field activity would, therefore, take away the high spirit that is in us and will make us weak and unstable, bad tempered and peevish. On the other hand, there are consequences of hard bodily exercise and high living with no attempt to cultivate the mind or use the intellect in study. At first the sense of physical fitness fills a man with self-confidence and energy and makes him twice the man he is. But suppose he does nothing else and holds himself aloof from any sort of culture? Then even if there is something in him that is capable of desiring knowledge, he is starved of instruction and is never encouraged to think for himself by taking part in rational discussions or intellectual pursuits of any kind. And so his mind grows feeble for lack of stimulus and nourishment, and deaf and blind because the darkness that clouds perception is never cleared away. Such a man ends by being wholly uncultivated and a hater of reason. Flaying no use for reasonable persuasion, he gains all his ends by savage violence, like a brute, and he lives in a dull stupor of ignorance with no touch of inward harmony or grace.

    On this point, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am supported by good authority and, with your permission, may I quote from the Republic of Plato on "the Education for the Guardians". This is the Conford Edition, Mr Speaker, Sir, at page 99 - middle of the page:

    'There are then these two elements in the soul - the spirited and the philosophic. And it is for their sake, as should say, and not (except incidentally) for the sake of the soul and body that heaven has given to mankind these two branches of education. The purpose is to bring the two elements into tune with one another by adjusting the tension of each to the right pitch. So one who can apply to the soul both kinds of education blended in perfect proportion

Column: 791

would be master of a nobler sort of musical harmony than was ever made by tuning the strings of the lyre.' Therefore, in our education system we must not only concentrate on literary education but also concentrate on what Plato calls, and I think it is generally called, physical education. In this connection, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I inquire of the Education Minister what has happened to the idea of setting up an elite school? This is a very important subject and perhaps Members here will be given an opportunity to consider fully the question before this elite school is set up.

    I am glad to note in the Budget that as usual Education has taken a lion's share in the coming year's expenditure. It is also noted that the emphasis is now shifting from primary education to secondary education. In this connection, it may be relevant to ask the Education Minister whether, and if so when, he would take steps to provide free secondary education?

    The Minister for Health (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): That may mean more taxes, you know.

    Mr Tang See Chim: On the question of primary education, Sir, it is noted that it is not compulsory, as was remarked by the Minister for Health. Perhaps the Minister for Education will note this and possibly will also introduce compulsory primary education.

    In a developing society, Mr Speaker, Sir, there is not only the question of general education, but also the question of technical education to be considered. I am glad to note in the Finance Minister's Budget Speech that steps are being taken to set up technical and vocational schools. I would like to inquire of the Education Minister whether steps are being taken to co-ordinate the education system in this respect and see that we get sufficient technicians for the requirements of our industries. I would also recommend to the Education Minister that he should coordinate with the Economic Development Board to see that the requirements of industry for technicians are met.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of what has been said by our Prime Minister at the opening of the Third Asian Teachers' Seminar that "teachers are anonymous, faceless, listless, etc.", may I know what immediate steps the Minister for Education is taking to rectify the situation?

    Mr Rajoo: I wish to draw the attention of the Minister for Education to certain inconsistencies in the matter of duties and responsibilities of the principals in primary and secondary schools. As a new nation which is determined to build up an identity and culture of its own and to equip its young to meet the changed conditions, we are all aware that a re-orientation in our thinking and action is important. In this connection, the role of our teachers and principals cannot be over-emphasised. I have come to understand that once a teacher becomes a principal, he tends to lose all contact with the classrooms and his students whom he is supposed to lead and inspire with his leadership. Instead he is bogged down with paper work by the Ministry which tends to reduce him more or less to a chief clerk.

3.15 p.m.

    It appears that most of the principal's work is to transmit instructions received from the Ministry to teachers and report for frivolous reasons personally to the Ministry. Letters sent by principals to the Ministry often do not receive proper attention or, in certain cases, the principals themselves dare not write a second reminder.

    In many of the large schools, principals and senior assistants, who are usually highly-paid Division I officers and experienced teachers, have to spend most of their time doing clerical work which could be done by Division III clerical officers. How then can we expect our principals, who are no more than mere transmitting agents, to be positive in their approach, to be creative and inspire those who are under their care?

    I would urge the Minister for Education to conduct a survey to find out

Column: 793

how many principals and senior assistants of schools have to devote their time to clerical work, and how much of this work could be undertaken by a clerk or an executive officer. I would suggest that all principals of schools should be allowed to teach at least one period a day in the classes. This arrangement will enable them to keep in touch with students and truly assess the progress of the school and the direction it is heading. By keeping in touch with their class-room conditions, they will be in a better position to understand the needs of teachers and the general attitude and outlook of the student body.

    It is also understood that some of the problems of principals stem from an inequitable distribution of teachers to schools. While some schools have too many teachers, thus enabling the teachers to have too many free periods a day, other schools are not adequately staffed.

    I would therefore urge the Minister for Education to give serious thought to this matter and revise the system so that principals of schools will be in a position to keep in touch with the students and project much-needed character into the schools.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, we all know that the vote for education is the largest for next year. I have two suggestions to make regarding education and schools.

    The first point is about the post allowance for principals - in other words, this allowance is to enable them to look after their schools better. But, in actual fact, the result is just the contrary, because once a principal gets a handsome pay with an additional post allowance, he will not like to lose his job and he will not like to take steps to get rid of anti-national elements in his school. He will appease these elements and will not take action against them.

    The other point is this. The Ministry of Education is not quite efficient in controlling the purchase and sale of text-books through the principals - the Member for Kampong Kembangan has raised the question of the purchase of

Column: 794

school text-books - because they are allowed a certain percentage of commission on the purchase of text-books. This means that they can make money out of such transactions and they, therefore, do not like the text-books to remain unchanged. A certain number of them just try to obtain a commission on the bills sent by the sellers of text-books without even looking into the details or taking the trouble to find out whether the books are worth the money. This does no good to our education and nation. Why should we then give such a big vote to education and waste so much allowance on the principals?

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I am an ex-principal, I think what the Member for Paya Lebar has said needs a little bit of clarification.

    In my 16 years in school, I must say that I have not known of a single principal in English medium schools who had anything to do with bookshops paying him a percentage. It might have happened in Chinese schools - and I must say that I have heard of that but not in English medium schools.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, our nation lays great emphasis on education. This can be seen especially when we are conducting every year primary school combined examinations and secondary school combined examinations with the object of checking the progress of students. This is very good. But if it is too good, then, of course, it will be excessive. There are principals of certain schools who are really not good. Although some students obtain over 60 per cent marks, they are asked to leave school to ensure that the school can get a better pass percentage in the combined examinations. What is the reason for this? I cannot understand it. If the students of a certain school get worse results than those of other schools, then there may be some reason for getting rid of the students.

    Just now the Member opposite me said that he had been a principal. I

Column: 795

was teaching in Indonesia before, and almost half of the students in my class could not pass an examination. I gave them extra tuition and many of them managed to become good students. So it is against the principle of education to sack students for poor results, more so as these students have around 65 per cent marks, just for prestige. You do not have to spend more time on the clever students. The bad students need more of the teacher's time and energy. So I hope that the Minister for Education will pay more attention to this and direct principals of schools not to sack such students. We should not chase them out of school but we should ask them to come back and improve their education so that they will be able to get 70, 80 or 90 per cent marks. It is not right to ask students to leave school so that the school can improve its passing percentage in the combined examinations, and therefore does not compare badly with other schools.
